newsitem.title: GERMANY: German retailers see 96 retail turnover down 1-pct.
newsitem.headline: German retailers see 96 retail turnover down 1-pct.

text.p: German retailers said on Thursday that retail sales in 1996 would probably fall one percent in real terms compared to the previous year.
But Walter Deuss, the chairman of Karstadt AG and head of the German Retail Association, said the industry hoped it could achieve a small rise in turnover in value terms in 1997.

In the first 10 months of 1996 the German retail industry reported a decline in turnover of 1.1 percent in real terms. Deuss said that the shopping spurt at the end of the year would not be strong enough to offset the decline.
"In real terms there should be a fall of one percent," he said in the text of a speech prepared for delivery at a news conference in Frankfurt.
This marks the fourth consecutive year of falling retail turnover in Germany.
Deuss said that a survey of the association's members showed that 85 percent expected "a more or less clear rise in turnover in nominal terms" in 1997.
This means that retailers could hope for a small rise in sales next year in value terms, he added.
